node.title: ‘The most epic love story possible’: Hannah Kent’s new lesbian romance
node.alt: A woman in her mid 30s smiles, she;s standing in a lush green garden
node.description: The Burial Rites author has gone in a new direction in her latest novel, Devotion, which follows two girls across oceans and spiritual planes.
node.content:
["Hannah Kent's first two novels were bleak explorations of historical crimes: her 2013 debut Burial Rites told the story of the last person executed in Iceland; 2016's The Good People, steeped in Irish folklore, focused on the murder of a young child.", "But the Australian author wanted to go in a different direction with her latest novel, Devotion.", "\"I was looking forward to stepping away from that very heavy material \u2014 murder,\" she told Claire Nichols on ABC RN's The Book Show.", "\"I wanted to step back into the light \u2026 I wanted to look at human connection.\"", "", "
Hannah Kent speaks to Claire Nichols
", "Devotion begins in 1836, with a community of Old Lutherans who have settled temporarily in the Prussian town of Kay.", "The novel's heroine, Hanne, is on the cusp of womanhood and struggling to meet the domestic expectations placed on her by her family and community.", "She also can't make a friend \u2014 until Thea and her family move to Kay.", "Kent had first set out to write a novel about female friendship. But when the same-sex marriage vote passed and her partner Heidi proposed, she realised she wanted to tell a different story.", "\"I was aware of having an audience initially, and what sort of story people might want to read about,\" she recalls.", "\"In the end, I just threw all caution to the wind and said: 'No, I want to write a love story that I can relate to and that pleases me \u2014 and if some people dislike that, well at least I'll enjoy reading it.'", "\"I have lived my entire life hungry for narratives that represent something akin to what I have experienced in my own life \u2026 [I wanted to write] something that I would have appreciated when I was younger, and something that my wife would like.", "With Kent's exquisite prose, Devotion follows Hanne and Thea across oceans and spiritual planes, taking their love story from Europe to Australia and playing thrillingly with history and fiction.", "
From Prussia with love
", "Kent never set out to become a historical fiction writer; when she studied creative writing at university, she intended to write plays.", "Instead, inspired by the story of Agnes Magnusdottir, she wrote Burial Rites. The novel was a commercial and critical hit, and is reportedly being adapted for screen by Luca Guadagnino (Call Me By Your Name), with Jennifer Lawrence to star.", "", "
In 2011, Kent won the inaugural Writing Australia Unpublished Manuscript Award for Burial Rites.(Supplied: Pan Macmillan Australia)
", "Kent appears to have carved out a narrow historical niche; all her novels take place in the 1820s and 1830s.", "\"It's certainly not intentional, but I probably do end up researching this time or writing about this time, because I often discover the seeds for future stories while I'm researching another book,\" she explains.", "\"In writing Devotion, I knew I wasn't going to suddenly jump to a contemporary novel; I didn't feel ready to. I had discovered through the process of the previous two novels that so much of my writing could be fed by the research process.", "Kent grew up in the Adelaide Hills, where she still lives, with her wife and two young children.", "The Adelaide Hills is also where Hanne, Thea and their community relocate to, seeking a new life free of religious persecution.", "They end up settling in Heiligendorf, a fictionalised version of Hahndorf, where these days tourists visit cuckoo clock shops and restaurants selling sauerkraut and ham hock.", "Kent herself is related to Old Lutheran families that came to South Australia after this first wave of migration.", "\"All these sorts of things [including the food and culture of persecuted Prussians] came together and started to seed a sense of a place, of a new landscape that I could write about.\"", "
Writing about Australia
", "Note: This article contains spoilers for the second half of the novel.", "Kent approached writing about Australian history with caution.", "\"I don't think I felt ready for it \u2014 but I didn't want to paint myself into a corner: I didn't want to end up being the person who just picks a murderous woman from history and subverts the narrative,\" she explains.", "But she knew writing about Australian colonial history would be difficult.", "\"I'm never going to write from an Aboriginal perspective. I'm not Aboriginal myself, that's not my place to take up. So I'm going to have to accord everything with the perspective of a white settler \u2026 [but] I didn't want to continually perpetuate those old ideologies.\"", "", "
Kent's first screenplay \u2014 Run Rabbit Run \u2014 is set to be filmed next year, starring Elisabeth Moss.(Supplied: Lauren Bamford)
", "Her solution to this dilemma was unexpected.", "On the arduous six-month journey from Prussia to Adelaide by boat, Hanne dies.", "But this isn't the end of her story: after death, Hanne becomes a ghost who follows Thea, her family and her community as they arrive in South Australia and build their new lives in Heiligendorf.", "\"By killing Hanne off, I enabled her to be free to educate herself essentially, and leave behind the beliefs of her community. Not only the religious beliefs, but also the attitudes towards First Nations peoples,\" says Kent.", "While writing Devotion, Kent consulted with Mandy Brown, a poet and elder of the Peramangk and Ngarrindjeri nations, to ensure her depictions of the Peramangk people were accurate.", "\"[Brown] really encouraged me to include the Peramangk's own belief in the supernatural, and their awareness of ghosts and ghostly presences, and that affected the ways in which Hanne relates to them as well,\" says Kent.", "Hanne respects and appreciates the Peramangk peoples and their land \u2014 in a way that many new arrivals in colonial Australia did not, finding the landscape harsh and incomprehensible.", "\"[I didn't want to have] someone just say that it's [this country] awful \u2014 even though that might be historically accurate,\" Kent explains.", "
History and fiction
", "Kent drew on the work of historians Dr Ian Harmstorf and David Schubert as well as firsthand accounts \u2014 including the captain's logbook of the Zebra \u2014 to capture, in fascinating detail, the physical challenges faced by the Old Lutherans in their journey and settlement.", "\"Initially, when I wrote this book, I thought I'd apply the same methodology that I had done with my previous two novels,\" she says.", "\"Because I was writing about cultures that were not my own, about places that I didn't really live in, I wanted to do my due diligence and make sure that everything that was in the page was historically accurate.\"", "", "
Kent had two children while writing Devotion:\u00a0\"I do sometimes credit the weirder aspects of this book with just being so tired during the writing of it.\"(Supplied: Pan Macmillan)
", "But when it came to Devotion, Kent was worried about offending relatives of the Old Lutherans \u2014 and so decided to turn more towards fiction.", "\"The other reason was that I couldn't find any evidence of any sort of queer love story [in my research]. So I knew that the central story was going to be fiction,\" says Kent.", "At first, Hanne and Thea are unable to wrap language around their romantic feelings.", "\"Part of this came from me reflecting on my own life and thinking: Had I been born in this time, would I have been able to name those feelings? I mean, I was unable to do so for so long in my own life,\" says Kent.", "\"But of course as the novel unfurls, it was important for me, for her [Hanne] to be able to talk very openly about her feelings, and for her to recognise them for what they are.\"", "
'Untainted by shame or by punishment'
", "Growing up, Kent had devoured Sarah Waters novels \u2014 including Tipping the Velvet, Affinity and Fingersmith \u2014 but observes that the narratives of Waters's books and other works of queer historical fiction were mired in secrecy, rejection and tragedy.", "", "
\u201cThere's a lot of myself in Hanne, particularly in my experience as an adolescent \u2026 I was a bit of a loner and I found it quite hard to fit in with my peers, but also \u2026 I loved to be in nature,\" says Kent.(ABC Arts: Sia Duff)
", "In contrast, she set out to write a love story \"that is on many levels pure and untainted by shame or by punishment\".", "Which is another reason she chose to kill off her protagonist.", "\"I knew that if she were to stay alive, the way I was writing it [the novel], her feelings for Thea and Thea's reciprocated feelings, something was going to have to come to a head,\" Kent explains.", "\"Either you're going to write a very dull book about two women in love with each other, who never act on it \u2026 or something's going to happen and they're going to be discovered, or excommunicated, or shamed by themselves.", "\"So even though this book is by no means a jolly novel, it's nonetheless a happier alternative to what would have otherwise been.\"", "Kent was also conscious of avoiding the 'bury your gays' trope.", "\"Even though the character dies in this, there's no subliminal message of punishment \u2026 by killing her off, she is finally free to be articulate about her love,\" she says.", "Devotion is out now through Pan Macmillan."]
